conversation.message: That is an excellent and crucial question. At Nursery B, fostering emotional regulation and positive peer relationships is foundational. Our approach is based on a clear, supportive behavioral framework. We focus heavily on teaching emotional literacy—helping children identify and articulate their feelings ('I see you are feeling frustrated'). When conflicts arise, we do not punish; rather, we use mediated problem-solving. This involves an educator guiding the children to discuss how their actions affected others and collaboratively finding a solution that satisfies everyone, emphasizing empathy and repair. We utilize positive reinforcement consistently to celebrate desired behaviors, ensuring the framework is supportive and focuses on teaching skills rather than just enforcing rules. We believe this supportive and clear structure allows every child to feel safe and understood. Does this approach align with the supportive environment you envision for your child?
